pr_title: Fix subscribe topic with end time not completing

timeline.message:
Fix subscribe topic with end time not completing

Signed-off-by: Steven Sheehy <steven.sheehy@hedera.com>

timeline.bodyText:
This kills historical queries that are still running (polling every 2 sec). lastTopicMessage is the last one processed, not last one in the system.
If you send a subscription request with endTime=now() with very old startTime on a big topic, it dies 30 seconds in regardless of if there is more data.
timeline.author: mike-burrage-hedera

replies.bodyText: Nice catch. I can't think of another solution (without introducing another query as you mention) to address this until we have separated historical and incoming in #542. When that occurs, we can just complete it once historical flow is complete and then run my current logic with some slight modification. Will keep this as is until that PR is complete
replies.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText:
If we know the last query for this subscription (has to be at least 1 completed query) definitely returned 0 records I think we can do something with that.
Could assume the "effective" timestamp processed so far was now() - 10 seconds (or 30 seconds or something like that), and if that timestamp > endTime we can complete the subscription. And if we received any messages > endTime we can complete.
Might be a pretty decent simple solution, and wouldn't require the additional query. It's an option.
Still edge cases it's not perfect on, but possibly better than the current situation.
replies.author: mike-burrage-hedera

replies.bodyText:
This is fixed now. With the split of historical and incoming, we can simply check if endTime is before time request was received after historical is complete.
Additionally, we check if incoming is complete by waiting for endTime to be after now, but with some buffer in between to ensure all messages are received.
replies.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText:
Deciding based on now and endTimeInterval is susceptible to

relative time skews between grpc server and nodes
delay in ingestion

One of the way to do this accurately would be - using latest consensus timestamp from t_timestamp table.
If latest consensus ts > filter's end time, then we know for sure that no new messages are arriving.
timeline.author: apeksharma

replies.bodyText:
Executing a separate query is

Slow
Won't work if there's no messages after endTime
Doesn't address completing incoming messages
replies.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.message:
Address review feedback

Signed-off-by: Steven Sheehy <steven.sheehy@hedera.com>

timeline.bodyText: q: why the preference for  replay and auto connect after 1 subscriber instead of just cache()
timeline.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: There's zero difference behind the scenes except that autoConnect gives you an overload to store the cancellation callback. Without that cancellation there were multiple shared pollers running concurrently during tests.
replies.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText:
in listen,  we should be just replaying the messages with timestamp after last seen timestamp of that particular subscriber.
Returning possible duplicates from one layer and filtering them in another layer doesn't seem right.
We should be building a system with stronger invariants than that.
timeline.author: apeksharma
